subject: Hobbies and Hobbits
header: Have I mentioned already that my long-time client, that once a few months asks me to do some urgent work has done so again? So I am totally busy writing a few small, Dancer-based, in-house web-apps.

entries.title: Learning the Perl Debugger: Introduction
entries.text: Chisel Wright started to teach his fellow Net-A-Porter employees how to use the built-in Perl debugger. He is now sharing the experience via GitHub.

entries.title: Perl references: create, dereference and debug with confidence
entries.text: Funnily, a day after I published an article explaining the various return values of the ref() command, David Farrell has also published an article explaining how to use references in Perl.

entries.title: New Catalyst Development Branch "Ancona" Ready for Commiters
entries.text: Do you use Catalyst? Are you interested in contributing to the code-base? John Napiorkowski has started the new round of development. He is looking forward to contribution in forms of patches, or comments, or at least votes on which features are more important to work on.

entries.title: An Organization for Alien::Base
entries.text: The Alien::* pacakegs make it easy to install non-perl dependencies using the cpan client. Alien::Base makes it easy to create Alien::* packages. As Joel Berger, the author of the module tells us, the module now have a GitHub 'organization' to keep maintain the source code.

entries.title: A CPAN client that works like a charm
entries.text: Gianluca Casati shows how to configure 'cpan', the standard CPAN client including some nice features like history and colors. Nowedays I usually use cpanminus, but when I have to use the cpan client this can be a really usefull reminder.

entries.title: Released Web::ChromeLogger
entries.text: Web::ChromeLogger is a ChromeLogger library for Perl5. Chrome Logger is a Google Chrome extension for debugging server side applications in the Chrome console. (by Matsuno Tokuhiro)

entries.title: Secure your passwords with KeePass and Perl
entries.text: David Farell shows how to use File::KeePass to store the passwords you use on various web sites.

entries.title: Perl Encryption Primer: Hashes
entries.text: Hashes are one-way mappings of data to something more or less unique. Algorithms that you might have heard about include MD5, SHA-1, SHA-2, implemented in modules in the Digest::* namespace. Timm Murray explains what are these hashing algorithms, when and how to use them, and what is the problem with birthday parties.

entries.title: Make Your Live Demo Flawless!
entries.text: Jeffrey Ryan Thalhammer created App::Cleo, a tool to create keyboard typing mock-ups. It can replay whatever you do in the terminal, making live demostrations nicer. A couple of other solutions are mentioned in the comment section including script/scriptreplay and IO::Prompter by Damian Conway.

entries.title: 3 Entrepreneurs Turn Hobbies Into Business Success
entries.text: American Express writing about 3 people including JT Smith, the creator of The Game Crafter, WebGUI, and Lacuna Expanse. (If you are wondering those are 3 hobbies, not hobbits, as I read at first.)

Perl/CGI script with Apache2
entries.text: While the recommended way to write modern web applications in Perl is using some PSGI based framework, you might be one of the many people out there who need to maintain CGI scripts. In that case this introduction can help you.

entries.title: ref - What kind of reference is this variable?
entries.text: The ref() function will return the type of the reference you passed in. There are a few commonly seen values such as SCALAR, ARRAY, HASH and maybe CODE, but there are a few others that we rarely see. In this article you'll see what are those references.

entries.title: Common Warnings and Error messages in Perl
entries.text: While the error messages of perl are exact, they are not always what a beginner needs to see. This is a collection of some of the most common errors and warnigs, with other explanations.
